output.organizationTypeJustification: The organization hosts publicly available course materials on GitHub, without any commercial or institutional branding, structured as community-driven repositories for doctoral school events, indicating an open source community rather than a formal university department or company.
output.description: GitHub organization hosting materials for the ALERT Geomaterials doctoral school, providing open-access course materials and resources on geomaterials (soil, rock, and related geotechnical topics) for doctoral students.
relatedToOrganization: ALERT Geomaterials – Alliance of Laboratories in Europe for Education, Research and Technology

relatedToOrganization.legalName: ALERT Geomaterials – Alliance of Laboratories in Europe for Education, Research and Technology
alternateNames: Alliance of Laboratories in Europe for Education, Research and Technology

disciplineJustification: The term “Geomaterials” and nature of doctoral school courses implies geotechnical engineering, a subfield of Civil engineering.
Geomaterials—study of soils, rocks, and sediments—falls within the domain of Earth science due to its focus on geological materials and processes.
output.relatedToEPFLJustification: A thorough review of all available data for the GitHub organization “alert-geomaterials” revealed no evidence linking it to EPFL. Specifically: 1) The organization name does not contain “EPFL” or any variant. 2) No description, README, or blog mentions EPFL, SDSC, or the Swiss Data Science Center. 3) There is no email or website on an epfl.ch domain. 4) There is no location set and no indication of being based in Lausanne, Switzerland. 5) The ROR record (alliance of laboratories) has no parent organization of EPFL or EPFL+ETH. 6) There are no parent organization links to EPFL or joint EPFL initiatives. As none of the weighted evidence categories apply, the cumulative confidence is 0.0 (below the 0.5 threshold), so this organization is not related to EPFL.

academicCatalogRelations.justification: Matched GitHub member handle 'edwardando' to the Infoscience author Andò, Edward via name similarity and profile lookup.

entity.title: Micromechanically inspired investigation of cemented granular materials: part I-from X-ray micro tomography to measurable model variables
entity.abstract: Cemented granular materials are abundant in nature and are often artificially produced. Their macroscopic behaviour is driven by small-scale material processes, which are generally classified as: grain breakage, cement damage and fragment rearrangement. This paper presents an experimental analysis of these processes using X-ray micro tomography data.

academicCatalogRelations.justification: Publication authored by Andò, Edward (member 'edwardando') in the field of granular materials/geotechnical research.

entity.title: Freezing-induced stiffness and strength anisotropy in freezing clayey soil: Theory, numerical modeling, and experimental validation
entity.abstract: This paper presents a combined experimental-modeling effort to interpret the coupled thermo-hydro-mechanical behaviors of the freezing soil, where an unconfined, fully saturated clay is frozen due to a temperature gradient. By leveraging the rich experimental data from microCT images and measurable model variables, the study quantifies stiffness and strength anisotropy.

academicCatalogRelations.justification: Publication authored by Andò, Edward (member 'edwardando') on clayey soil mechanics relevant to geomaterials.

entity.title: Influence of depositional fabric on mechanical properties of naturally deposited sands
entity.abstract: Fabric characteristics and shear deformation behaviour were analysed in four intact small-scale samples of naturally deposited sand. Triaxial compression tests were performed to evaluate the role of depositional fabric on mechanical properties.

academicCatalogRelations.justification: Publication authored by Andò, Edward (member 'edwardando') on granular material behavior relevant to geomaterials.
